title: fa.functional analysis - Uniqueness of solution to Cauchy problem with quadratic nonlinearity
body: Consider the non-linear differential operator $$\mathfrak{L}: \ C^2((0,T)\times\mathbb{R}^2)\ni\varphi\equiv\varphi(t,x,y) \, \mapsto \, \partial_x^2\varphi + (\partial_x\varphi)^2.$$ For $U\subset\mathbb{R}^2$ open and bounded with smooth boundary $\Gamma:=\partial U$ and $T>0$ , can you guarantee that the (smooth classical) solution to the Cauchy-problem $$\left\{\begin{aligned}\label{lem:ContrastiveDiffusions:eq2} \partial_t\varphi \ &= \ \mathfrak{L}\varphi\quad &&\text{in } \ (0,T)\times U,\\ \partial_x\partial_y\varphi \ &= \ 0 \quad &&\text{on } \ \{T\}\times\Gamma, \end{aligned}\right.$$ with initial condition $\lim_{t\rightarrow 0+}\varphi = \delta(x-y)$ , is unique? (Given that the answer is not immediate, references to the literature are appreciated.) fa.functional-analysis ap.analysis-of-pdes ca.classical-analysis-and-odes mp.mathematical-physics parabolic-pde Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Aug 4, 2020 at 17:11 asked Aug 4, 2020 at 15:33 cts12 51 4 4 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 3 2 $\begingroup$ Do you really want the boundary condition only at t=T? The existing solution $\varphi$ that I found is a probability density (modelling the transition probability of a stochastic system to jump from state $x$ to state $y$ in $t>0$ units of time). Yes, I want the boundary at $t=T$ only. $\endgroup$ cts12 –  cts12 2020-08-04 17:14:32 +00:00 Commented Aug 4, 2020 at 17:14 1 $\begingroup$ Writing $\phi=\log v$ leads to the heat equation $v_t=v_{xx}$ but the boundary condition looks more complicate. $\endgroup$ Giorgio Metafune –  Giorgio Metafune 2020-08-10 08:32:16 +00:00 Commented Aug 10, 2020 at 8:32 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
